metadata.titleEn: Slope adaptive waveform metrics of the global ecosystem dynamics investigation system (GEDI-SAWA)
metadata.description: The dataset is the slope adaptive waveform index product of the Global Ecosystem Dynamics Investigation (GEDI), abbreviated as GEDI-SAWA, aimed at reducing the impact of terrain slope on the evaluation of forest vertical structure and aboveground carbon storage using a 25 m GEDI large spot laser waveform. The dataset spans from April 18, 2019 to March 16, 2023, with a total storage capacity of 51.0 TB and a total of 73473 tracks of data. The data is organized based on the date of acquisition (in days). The file is stored in hdf5 format and named in the same way as the official products released by GEDI. For example, the GEDI-SAWA file with the file name "GEDI02-C1_sawa_2019108002012-O01959_1-T03909_202-003_1-V002.h5" corresponds to the GEDI L1B file with the file name "GEDI01-B_2019108002012-O01959_1-T03909_2-003_1-V002.h5". The field name "RHT" in GEDI-SAWA refers to the slope adaptive waveform index at different energy percentiles. Each spot records 24 SAWA indices at different energy heights, corresponding to the 5th, 10th, 15th,..., 85th, 90th, 95th, 96th, 97th, 98th, 99th, and 100th energy percentiles. It is worth noting that the RHT field in the SAWA file is in centimeters (cm) and stored in integer format. To convert to a universal unit of meters (m), it needs to be multiplied by a conversion coefficient (0.01).
metadata.instructions: File Name: GEDI-SAWA is stored in HDF5 format, taking the file "GEDI02-C1-sawa_2019108002012-O01959_1-T03909_22-003_1V002. h5" as an example, where GEDI02-C1-sawa is the SAWA data product tag name, 2019 108002012 is the data acquisition time, which is 00:20:12 on the 108th day of 2019, O01959_1-T03909 is the satellite trajectory code, and 02:03_1-V002 is the data version tag. The naming conventions for L1B and L2A released by the GEDI-SAWA and GEDI teams are consistent. For example, the L1B and L2A files corresponding to the above files are "GEDI01-B_2019108002012-O01959_1-T03909_22-003:001_V002. h5" and "GEDI02-A_2019108002012-O01959_1-T03909_22-003:001_V002. h5" respectively“

background: Waveform broadening effects of large-footprint lidar caused by terrain slopes are still a great challenge limiting the estimation accuracy of forest aboveground biomass (AGB) over mountainous areas. The role of remote sensing in the accounting of global carbon budgets has been widely recognized, and several regional remotely sensed estimations/maps have been released. The limited capability of either the multispectral reflectance or the radar backscattering coefficients on the quantifying of carbon storage has been widely demonstrated due to the lack of physical basis and is always restricted by the sensitivity saturations and terrain effects. The forest carbon storage in vegetation is directly determined by forest spatial structures depicted by tree sizes, stem densities, and forest types. Spaceborne large-footprint lidar plays an important role in the existing global maps as well as the near-future remote sensing schemes of forest carbon storages. However, the biggest challenge limiting the estimation accuracy of forest AGB over mountainous areas is the waveform broadening effect caused by terrain slopes, i.e., the canopy and ground returns tend to be stretched and mixed up over steep topographies.
research objective: This study made full validation of slope-adaptive metrics using data acquired by the Global Ecosystem Dynamics Investigation (GEDI) mission, meanwhile exploring GEDI waveforms on estimations of forest AGB. In order to make full validation of slope-adaptive metrics using data acquired by the GEDI mission, meanwhile exploring GEDI waveforms on estimations of forest AGB, this study reports the assessment of slope-adaptive metrics of waveforms using GEDI data for estimations of forest aboveground biomass over mountainous areas.
challenges: However, its validation was limited by the unavailability of enough reference data. It is difficult to collect enough reference data by field measurements, especially over steep terrain conditions.
dataset: The reference forest AGB was calculated using the normalized points and the prediction model developed by Nelson et al., of which R2 is 0.71, which is acceptable to serve as reference data to make comparisons of the performance of different waveform metrics, although it may not be as accurate as those specifically developed based on the field measurements of forest plots if we have them. The global dataset acquired by GEDI after April 18, 2019, has been released since February 07, 2020. Two GEDI datasets came across the study area as shown by yellow lines in Figure 1(a). The nominal footprint size is about 25 m in diameter.
findings: The RHT and WP metrics gave the best and the worst estimation accuracy, respectively. RHT further improved R2 to 0.77 and decreased RMSE to 13.0 Mg/ha using terrain slopes extracted from SRTM DEM with a resolution of 1 arc second. R2 of estimation models based on RHT was finally improved to 0.8 with RMSE decreased to 11.7 Mg/ha using exact terrain slopes from ALS data. This study demonstrated the great potential of slope-adaptive metrics of GEDI waveforms on estimations of forest aboveground biomass over mountainous areas.

background: The effect of terrain slope on large footprint lidar waveforms is still a great challenge to the accurate mapping of forest aboveground biomass (AGB), although previous studies have made significant progress for slopes lower than 15°. Forests are important components of terrestrial ecosystems, containing approximately 80% of aboveground carbon (Dixon et al., 1994). Accurate mapping of forest aboveground biomass (AGB) is essential for research on the global carbon cycle (Brown et al., 1996).

Methods for measuring forest AGB, such as field measurements, are time-consuming and labor-intensive. Remote sensing methods are feasible for measuring forest AGB at regional and global scales. Multispectral remote sensing and radio detection and ranging (radar) techniques are widely used to estimate AGB. However, signal saturation problems occur when AGB reaches a certain level. The sensitivity of multispectral reflectance or radar backscattering coefficients to forest AGB is combined with uncertainties caused by the diversity of the forest's spatial structure. Lidar can overcome the saturation problem and improve the accuracy of AGB estimation because of its direct detection of the vertical forest structure. The Geoscience Laser Altimeter System (GLAS) was designed to acquire large footprint lidar waveforms with global coverage. Many studies have demonstrated that GLAS data can be used to measure forest canopy height and AGB. However, most previous studies focused on relatively flat terrain conditions. The terrain effect is a major challenge for measuring forest heights and AGB. Many studies have been carried out to reduce the impact of terrain on the retrieval of forest structure using large footprint lidar waveforms.

The GLAS data used in this study are the GLA01 and GLA14 products acquired from October 2003 to November 2006 and released by the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC). The study area is located in the Xishuangbanna region (21°08′–22°36′ N, 99°56′–101°50′ E), which is in southern Yunnan Province, China. Most of the region is mountainous. The main forest types include tropical seasonal rainforest and tropical mountain rainforest. The annual precipitation ranges from 1100mm to 2400mm. The GLAS stopped operating in 2009, but it is difficult to obtain better field measurements over the GLAS footprints. The ZELIG model has been well parameterized in the Howland forest in Maine, USA. The outputs of the ZELIG model were recorded at a 5-year interval from 5 years to 200 years for each succession sequence (i.e., 40 forest ages). The terrain slopes have two effects on the waveforms of forest stands. First, the width of the ground return is broadened, and the peak of the ground return decreases and is mixed with that of the forest canopy due to the stretching effect of the terrain slope. The second effect is that the relative vertical positions of trees also change as the slope increases.
The effect of terrain slope on lidar waveforms is still a challenge to the accurate estimation of forest AGB, especially over steep terrain.
research objective: A new method was proposed to calculate slope-adaptive waveform metrics for forest AGB mapping over mountainous areas.

The proposed method is referred to as PIPE because the bare ground waveform is modeled for a Plane Inclined, and the waveforms are aligned by the Point of signal Ending. The results using both simulated waveforms and GLAS data showed that the canopy height metrics extracted by the PIPE method gave the best estimation of forest AGB of the three methods.
This study proposed the PIPE method to extract canopy height metrics for the estimation of forest AGB considering terrain.
This study proposed the PIPE method for the estimation of forest AGB using data of lidar waveforms while considering the terrain.
challenges: The terrain effect is a major challenge for measuring forest heights and AGB. Previous studies have shown that the effects of terrain slope on the estimation of forest AGB have not been thoroughly addressed, although existing research has made significant progress in the use of GLAS waveforms on slopes lower than 15°. The ground peak gradually decreases and finally disappears as the terrain slope increases because the ground returns are stretched and mixed with vegetation returns. It is difficult to accurately extract canopy height metrics due to the difficulty in identifying the ground peak positions.

The GLAS stopped operating in 2009, but it is difficult to obtain better field measurements over the GLAS footprints. The PIPE method is only applicable to lidar waveforms acquired over areas where an elevation dataset is available. Although the terrain slopes from SRTM were used in the examination of the proposed method with the GLAS data, it must be emphasized that the proposed method is independent of SRTM data.
The effect of terrain slope on lidar waveforms is still a challenge to the accurate estimation of forest AGB, especially over steep terrain.
methods: First, a theoretical model was proposed to calculate lidar waveforms of bare ground with known terrain slopes. The forest waveform and its corresponding calculated bare ground waveform were then aligned by the signal ending points. Their energy quartiles were extracted separately by taking the signal ending points as references. The height differences between the corresponding energy quartiles were defined as slope-adaptive waveform metrics, which were then used as independent variables for the estimation of the forest AGB. The proposed method was examined with both simulated lidar waveforms of forest stands and real waveforms acquired by the Geoscience Laser Altimeter System (GLAS).

A simulated waveform of bare ground with a known slope was used to extract newly defined metrics from the lidar waveform. The newly defined canopy height metrics were used as independent variables for the estimation of forest AGB using both simulated lidar waveforms of forest stands and GLAS data.
dataset: Two typical footprint sizes (i.e., 25m and 70m in diameter) and 21 terrain slopes (i.e., from 0° to 40° at an interval of 2°) were used in the simulation of the lidar waveforms. The terrain slopes of the GLAS waveforms were between 5.54° and 34.08°.

The GLAS data used in this study are the GLA01 and GLA14 products acquired from October 2003 to November 2006 and released by the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC). The study area is located in the Xishuangbanna region (21°08′–22°36′ N, 99°56′–101°50′ E), which is in southern Yunnan Province, China. Field inventories were carried out in October 2010 over 26 GLAS footprints located within the Menglun Nature Reserve and the Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (XTBG, CAS). The GLAS data used in this study are the product of version 31, which was released in May 2010.
findings: The results showed that the terrain stretching on the forest waveform could be compensated for by the bare ground waveform. Compared with the Gaussian decomposition and waveform parameter methods, the proposed method gave the best estimation of the forest AGB with R2=0.92 and RMSE=15.95Mg/ha using simulated waveforms with a footprint size of 70m and R2=0.84 and RMSE=34.99Mg/ha using the GLAS waveforms. The results demonstrated that the proposed method had great potential for the estimation of forest AGB using lidar waveforms over mountainous areas.
The results using both simulated waveforms and GLAS data showed that the canopy height metrics extracted by the PIPE method gave the best estimation of forest AGB of the three methods.

The proposed PIPE method is not sensitive to the slope. For slopes of 0°–40°, the proposed PIPE method gives the best estimation of forest AGB of all three methods with R2=0.90 and RMSE=18.00Mg/ha. Under these conditions, the performance of the proposed PIPE method is outstanding. Over the full range of slopes of 0°–40°, the proposed PIPE method gives the best estimation of forest AGB, with R2=0.92 and RMSE=15.95Mg/ha. Similar to the results of the simulated waveforms, the PIPE method gives the best estimation of forest AGB with R2=0.84 and RMSE=34.99Mg/ha.

The performance of the proposed PIPE method was outstanding. The influence of terrain slope on the estimation of forest AGB using the canopy height metrics extracted by the PIPE method was weak or nearly negligible. Over the full range of terrain slopes of 0°–40°, the PIPE method gave the best estimation of forest AGB, with R2=0.92 and RMSE=15.95Mg/ha for a footprint size of 70m. The estimations of forest AGB using GLAS data and field measurements confirm the conclusions from the simulated lidar waveforms. The PIPE method gave the best estimation of forest AGB, with R2=0.84 and RMSE=34.99Mg/ha. The results of this study showed that the proposed method has great potential for the estimation of forest AGB using lidar waveforms while considering terrain.

Definition.Question: What is the 'slope-adaptive waveform index' in the context of the Global Ecosystem Dynamics Investigation (GEDI)?
Definition.Answer: The 'slope-adaptive waveform index' refers to a set of metrics designed to reduce the impact of terrain slopes on the assessment of forest vertical structures and aboveground carbon storage using large-footprint lidar waveforms from the Global Ecosystem Dynamics Investigation (GEDI). These indices, particularly the RHT index, record energy height at different percentiles and are adapted to account for terrain-induced waveform broadening.

Definition.Question: How is 'forest aboveground biomass (AGB) estimation' affected by terrain slopes in large-footprint lidar measurements?
Definition.Answer: Terrain slopes affect 'forest aboveground biomass (AGB) estimation' by causing waveform broadening in large-footprint lidar measurements. This broadening effect stretches the canopy and ground returns, making it difficult to accurately distinguish and measure forest structures, particularly in mountainous areas.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of simulation in developing data collection methods for lidar-based forest AGB estimation?
Definition.Answer: Simulation plays a significant role in developing data collection methods for lidar-based forest AGB estimation by allowing researchers to model and test the effects of various terrain slopes on lidar waveforms. Simulated lidar waveforms help in refining slope-adaptive metrics and methods, such as the PIPE method, which improve the accuracy of AGB estimation over complex terrains.

Comparison.Question: How do slope-adaptive waveform indices from the GEDI-SAWA dataset compare to traditional multispectral reflectance or radar backscattering coefficients in estimating forest aboveground biomass (AGB) in terms of accuracy and terrain adaptability?
Comparison.Answer: Slope-adaptive waveform indices from the GEDI-SAWA dataset are designed to address terrain slope effects which are challenging for multispectral reflectance or radar backscattering coefficients due to their sensitivity saturations and terrain effects. The GEDI-SAWA indices, particularly the RHT metric, have shown improved accuracy in estimating forest AGB over mountainous areas by mitigating waveform broadening effects caused by slopes.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences between using the GEDI and GLAS datasets for estimating forest aboveground biomass (AGB) in mountainous regions, considering the challenges posed by terrain slopes?
Comparison.Answer: The GEDI dataset, equipped with slope-adaptive metrics, aims to reduce the impact of terrain slopes on waveform assessments, whereas the GLAS dataset, previously used for similar purposes, faced challenges with terrain effects, especially on slopes greater than 15°. The GEDI dataset has shown improved estimation accuracy in mountainous areas, while the GLAS dataset's performance was limited by terrain stretching effects and the difficulty of accurately identifying ground peak positions.

Interpretation.Question: How can slope-adaptive waveform metrics be utilized to improve the accuracy of estimating forest aboveground biomass (AGB) in mountainous areas?
Interpretation.Answer: Slope-adaptive waveform metrics, such as those derived from the GEDI mission, can be used to counteract the waveform broadening effects caused by terrain slopes. This improves the accuracy of forest AGB estimation by effectively distinguishing between canopy and ground returns, even over steep topographies, enhancing the reliability of remote sensing data in assessing forest carbon storage.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges do researchers face when collecting reference data for validating slope-adaptive metrics in forest AGB estimation, and how might these challenges be addressed?
Interpretation.Answer: Researchers face challenges in collecting enough reference data through field measurements, particularly in steep terrain conditions. One approach to address this is to use alternative data sources like terrain slopes extracted from high-resolution digital elevation models (e.g., SRTM DEM) or airborne lidar data to validate and refine slope-adaptive metrics, thereby enhancing their application in diverse terrains.

Interpretation.Question: What potential benefits can be inferred from using large-footprint lidar datasets in the context of global carbon budget accounting?
Interpretation.Answer: Large-footprint lidar datasets, such as those from the GLAS and GEDI missions, offer the potential to accurately depict forest spatial structures and aboveground biomass by overcoming limitations like signal saturation and terrain effects found in other remote sensing methods. This capability significantly contributes to global carbon budget accounting by providing detailed insights into forest carbon storage across varied landscapes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the primary reasons that terrain slopes impact the accuracy of waveform data collected by large-footprint lidar?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The primary reasons that terrain slopes impact the accuracy of waveform data collected by large-footprint lidar include the stretching and mixing of canopy and ground returns over steep topographies. This waveform broadening effect makes it challenging to accurately estimate forest aboveground biomass, especially in mountainous areas.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to collect sufficient reference data for validating forest aboveground biomass estimation models in steep terrain conditions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: It is challenging to collect sufficient reference data in steep terrain conditions because field measurements are difficult to conduct in such environments. The unavailability of enough reference data limits the validation of estimation models, necessitating alternative or enhanced data collection methods.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the limitations in using multispectral reflectance and radar backscattering coefficients for quantifying carbon storage in forest ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The limitations in using multispectral reflectance and radar backscattering coefficients for quantifying carbon storage arise from their lack of a physical basis and issues with sensitivity saturations and terrain effects. These factors restrict their capability to accurately estimate carbon storage, especially compared to lidar, which can directly detect vertical forest structures.

Causal Consequence.Question: What impact does the availability of elevation datasets have on the applicability of lidar-based methods for forest AGB estimation over steep terrains?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The availability of elevation datasets is crucial as it allows for the application of methods like the PIPE method that rely on known terrain slopes to calculate slope-adaptive waveform metrics. Without such datasets, it becomes challenging to accurately estimate forest aboveground biomass using lidar waveforms over steep terrains.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to validate slope-adaptive metrics using data from spaceborne lidar systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to validate slope-adaptive metrics to ensure the accuracy of forest aboveground biomass estimations, as these metrics help account for the waveform broadening effects caused by terrain slopes, which is a significant challenge in mountainous regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures can be followed to mitigate the effects of terrain slope on the accuracy of lidar waveform data when estimating forest aboveground biomass?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A proposed method involves calculating slope-adaptive waveform metrics for forest AGB mapping by using lidar waveforms over mountainous areas. This includes modeling bare ground waveforms for a plane inclined and aligning them by the point of signal ending. By extracting energy quartiles separately using the signal ending points as references, the height differences between corresponding energy quartiles are used as slope-adaptive waveform metrics for AGB estimation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can researchers ensure the validation of slope-adaptive metrics when using global ecosystem dynamics data for forest biomass estimation?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Validation can be achieved by using reference forest AGB calculated through normalized points and prediction models, such as those developed by Nelson et al. With an R2 value of 0.71, these models provide a basis for comparison, though they may not be as accurate as metrics specifically developed from field measurements. Using terrain slopes extracted from SRTM DEM or ALS data can further improve the estimation models.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps should be taken to simulate lidar waveforms for different terrain slopes to improve the estimation of forest structure?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To simulate lidar waveforms, researchers can use typical footprint sizes and a range of terrain slopes. A theoretical model can be used to calculate lidar waveforms of bare ground with known terrain slopes. The forest waveform and its corresponding calculated bare ground waveform are then aligned by the signal ending points, and the slope-adaptive waveform metrics are extracted to serve as independent variables for estimating forest AGB.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the accurate estimation of forest aboveground biomass (AGB) over steep terrain using lidar data?
Enablement.Answer: Slope-adaptive waveform metrics and methods like the PIPE technique can be used to address the terrain effect on lidar waveforms, enabling more accurate estimation of forest AGB over steep terrain by compensating for the waveform broadening effects caused by slopes.

Enablement.Question: How do slope-adaptive metrics facilitate the reduction of terrain-induced errors in lidar-based forest structure assessments?
Enablement.Answer: Slope-adaptive metrics are designed to account for waveform broadening effects due to terrain slopes, thus improving estimation accuracy by providing a more precise assessment of forest vertical structure and aboveground biomass, especially in mountainous areas.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary for implementing a slope-adaptive approach in the analysis of lidar datasets for forest biomass mapping?
Enablement.Answer: Implementing a slope-adaptive approach requires the availability of accurate terrain slope data, such as those extracted from SRTM DEM or ALS data, to adjust waveform metrics and improve the estimation of forest aboveground biomass over varying topographies.

Expectation.Question: Why is it challenging to obtain enough reference data for validating slope-adaptive metrics using field measurements, especially in steep terrain conditions?
Expectation.Answer: It is difficult to collect enough reference data by field measurements over steep terrain conditions, which limits validation efforts.

Expectation.Question: What are the anticipated reasons for the challenges associated with accurately extracting canopy height metrics from lidar waveforms over steep terrain?
Expectation.Answer: The challenges arise from terrain effects such as the broadening of waveforms, stretching and mixing of canopy and ground returns, and the difficulty in identifying ground peak positions.

Expectation.Question: Why might the existing global dataset acquired after a certain date be inadequate for validating the estimation models of forest aboveground biomass in mountainous areas?
Expectation.Answer: The existing dataset may be inadequate due to the limited availability of reference data specifically developed based on field measurements of forest plots, which affects the accuracy of comparisons.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential limitations of using large-footprint lidar data for forest AGB estimation in steep terrain areas?
Judgmental.Answer: A major limitation is the waveform broadening effect where canopy and ground returns are mixed over steep terrains, which can affect the accuracy of AGB estimation. Additionally, collecting sufficient reference data for validation remains a challenge, especially over steep terrain conditions.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could future datasets be expanded or refined to improve the estimation of forest AGB using remote sensing methods?
Judgmental.Answer: Future datasets could be expanded by incorporating more detailed and accurate terrain slope data, possibly from higher-resolution elevation datasets or advanced lidar systems. Additionally, integrating field measurements where feasible could enhance validation efforts and refine the estimation models.

Assertion.Answer: Terrain slopes can significantly affect the accuracy of large-footprint lidar waveforms, stretching and mixing canopy and ground returns. To address this, slope-adaptive metrics have been developed, such as the GEDI-SAWA product, which uses a slope-adaptive waveform index to improve estimation accuracy. These metrics consider terrain effects and adjust the waveform data accordingly, enhancing the accuracy of forest aboveground biomass estimations over mountainous areas.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the techniques used to validate the accuracy of forest aboveground biomass estimation over steep terrains.
Assertion.Answer: Validation of forest aboveground biomass estimation over steep terrains is challenging due to the difficulty in collecting sufficient reference data from field measurements. However, techniques such as using normalized points and prediction models, as well as slope-adaptive waveform metrics like RHT, have been developed to improve estimation accuracy. These methods have been validated using datasets from the GEDI mission and compared with reference data to assess their performance.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate the data collection methods used for acquiring lidar waveforms for forest aboveground biomass estimation and their adaptations to terrain effects.
Request/Directive.Answer: Spaceborne large-footprint lidar, such as that from the GEDI mission, is used for acquiring global lidar waveforms. These waveforms are sensitive to terrain slopes, which can cause broadening effects that mix canopy and ground returns. Methods like the PIPE approach model bare ground waveforms for inclined planes and align waveforms using signal ending points to extract slope-adaptive metrics, addressing the challenges posed by terrain effects.
